online.game
Class cell<FINALTYPE extends cell<FINALTYPE>>

java.lang.Object
  online.game.cell<FINALTYPE>
All Implemented Interfaces:
OnlineConstants
Direct Known Subclasses:
ccell, chipCell, stackCell
public abstract class cell<FINALTYPE extends cell<FINALTYPE>>
extends java.lang.Object
implements OnlineConstants

this is the common cell which can be used by all boards. Actual boards are normally use a subclass of this one. The different numbering schemes for rows and columns do not affect the representation at this level.

cells logically correspond to squares of the board. They have row and column coordinates. The keep pointers the neighboring cells, so it is possible to navigate without respect to the coordinate system. They also keep track of the board's contents. Disembodied cells (not part of the board) are commonly used to store other object of interest so the code can be written to always manipulate cells.

Specialized subclasses of cell exist for common variations in geometry, and the default board construction process automatically initializes a grid of neighbors with geometry appropriate to the board.

Author:
ddyer
See Also:
chipCell, stackCell

Field Detail

geometry

public cell.Geometry geometry
the geometry of this cell, which is also the number of neighbors the cell has. Note that some board have edges, and therefore the neighbors are null, while others are fully connected into or torus so the neighbors are never null. It's also possible to manipulate the default connectivity to create other special forms, such as the "hole" in the center of the tzaar board, or the oddly interconnected grid of octagons and squares in Octiles.

rackLocation

public int rackLocation
an integer code for the "location" of this cell. This is typically used by mouse tracking to indicate what sort of object was hit.

onBoard

public boolean onBoard
true if this cell is "on the board"

linkCount

public int linkCount
the number of other real cells linked to from this cell. If link count is less than geometry, the the cell is an edge of some sort.

next

public FINALTYPE extends cell<FINALTYPE> next
all the cells on the board are linked through the "next" field, so it's possible to traverse all the cells on the board (in no particular order) by starting at the board "allCells" and following the "next" links.

adjacent

public FINALTYPE extends cell<FINALTYPE>[] adjacent
the adjacent cells. Standard board creation will link these up after all the initial cells are created. These adjacent cells normally form a circle, but some directions lead off the board and are empty. this is the convenient way to transit from one cell to and adjacent one

these adjacent cells are normally acessed by the exitToward method.

col

public char col
the cell column.

row

public int row
the cell row.

randomv

public long randomv
a random number which serves as the "identity" of this cell for Digest()

Method Detail

copyFrom

public abstract void copyFrom(FINALTYPE from)
copy the contents of this cell from "from". This method is typically wrapped by subclasses encapsulate the copy process.

the copy process should be aware of shared structure in the cell contents, but shouldn't copy or alter the cell's geometry

Parameters:
from -

exitTo

public FINALTYPE exitTo(int dir)
this is the convenient way to traverse a row, column, or diagonal we expect the directions to be 0-n, but for convenient we accept anything modulo the geometry of the cell use gBoard.findDirectrion to convert coordinates to these directions

Parameters:
dir - The directions are numbered 0 through n-1 (n=3,4,6, or 8 depending on the grid.) the directions will form a clockwise circle, and direction x+n/2 is opposite direction n. Usually, it's not relevant how these directions map into the board's coordinate system. if it does matter, use the board's class variables Direction_Row_Plus etc. as seed values.
Returns:
the cell found in the desired direction, or null if it doesn't exist.

countLinks

public void countLinks()
re-count the links

isEdgeCell

public boolean isEdgeCell()
Note that this reflects reality immediately after the board is created, before and cells or other links are explicitly removed.

Returns:
true if this cell has at least one null link.

pointInsideCell

public boolean pointInsideCell(HitPoint pt,
                               int x,
                               int y,
                               int SQ)
this method is made visible so you can tweak the radius that constututes a hit. Note that the target is a smaller square, not a circle.

Parameters:
pt - the mouse location
x - x position of the chip
y - y position of the chip
SQ - square cell size of the chip
Returns:
true of point pt is insidide the square centered at x,y
See Also:
drawChipHighlight, drawChip, drawStack

drawChip

public boolean drawChip(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                        chip piece,
                        exCanvas drawOn,
                        HitPoint highlight,
                        int SQUARESIZE,
                        int e_x,
                        int e_y,
                        java.lang.String thislabel)
draw the chip contained in this cell, and note if the mouse is inside. The actual drawing is done by the chip's drawChip method.

Parameters:
gc - the graphic context to draw on (can be null)
piece - the chip to draw
drawOn - the canvas to draw on (corresponding to gc)
highlight - contains the mouse position, receives info about the hit if any
SQUARESIZE - scale te picture to this size
e_x - x center of the square
e_y - y center of the square
thislabel - after drawing, superimpose this text
Returns:
true if the mouse hit this object.

draw a chip and test for mouse sensitivity

drawOn - // the canvas to do the drawing

e_x - // the center of the object
e_y - // the center y of the object
thislabel - // label to print on top
